newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.N. dismisses German report on Iraqi air strike.
newsitem.headline: U.N. dismisses German report on Iraqi air strike.

text.p: U.N. officials and knowledgable diplomats on Tuesday dismissed a German newspaper report that the United States was contemplating a strike against Iraq.

"We continue to have significant problems in all the areas-- including the missile area," said Charles Duelfer, the American deputy director of the U.N. Special Commission in charge of eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

"We believe they may have an operational missile force. but there is nothing we have discovered recently that would provoke this (news) report," he said, referring to an article in the Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper.
Rolf Ekeus, director of the commission, is currently in Bonn before going to Moscow later this week.
Envoys from the United States and Western European missions, who follow developments closely, said they were baffled by the reports from Germany.
But diplomats said that there was evidence, as the paper reported, showing that Iraqi engineers had worked on a secret long-range missile program between July and September 1992.
They said there was no direct proof that the work had still been going on recently, but said it was however "highly probable."
